newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli officers gambled while on Holocaust tour.
newsitem.headline: Israeli officers gambled while on Holocaust tour.

text.p: Israel ordered its army on Thursday to investigate the behaviour of commanders-in-training who gambled their nights away at Polish casinos while touring Nazi Holocaust death camps by day.

Defence Minister Yitzhak Mordechai demanded the army immediately launch an investigation and submit "conclusions and recommendations" after it admitted several officers had visited casinos two or three times during the trip to Poland.
Israel Radio said nearly 60 officers at the Jewish state's School of High Command hit hotel casinos for six nights.

It said they also played cards while on the bus to the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp, where the Nazis killed at least a million of the six million Jews they systematically exterminated during World War Two.

"We are speaking of seven, eight officers and not the whole group who during the two or three nights visited casinos and that in itself testifies to poor judgment," Brigadier-General Yossi Raveh, commander of the school, told the radio.
"It's a lack of sensitivity even for a private visit and certainly when it's a visit on the part of the army and an official visit for that matter," he said.
Raveh had said he was unsure whether disciplinary steps would be necessary. Overall the tour was respectable and emotional, and top officers had been moved to tears, he said.
But he added further educational steps were needed.
"We must examine how we got to this situation," he said. "It's certainly judgment we are sorry about."
